title: OER Impact: Collaboration, Evidence, Synthesis
segmentation: So this is how I'm going to break this down.

First of all, I'm gonna tell you a bit about the project, then some of the collaborative work that we've been doing with our research partners talking a bit about the model of evidence that we used to assess impact the way we are and then talk about how we're trying to synthesize what we found and what others have found into one complete picture about our impact and how we're using mapping to do this.
If you are tweeting about this session, please use the hashtag or we are map and we're going to come back to that later on and try and do something with it.
So there we are.
Researcher Project is based at the Open University were funded by the Hewlett Foundation.
We have a research team led by two professors and our job is really to try and build the most comprehensive understanding of what happens when you use ovr.
What difference does it actually make, if any, of you do research into how we are, then you'll appreciate.
There are some difficulties around how you assess impact.
We work across different educational sectors, so we have some collaborations.
In higher education something school we also do work with.
Colleges want some of the work that I've been doing and how I originally met.
Larry was through my work with the Community College sector in the United States.
The the project website address are we our research hub.org and the hashtag is O ER our hub.
So in terms of the work that we're doing.
I've said a little bit about some of this or this, or evidence gap that can be said to exist around the impact of Ovr.
There's definitely a need for this evidence, so a lot of the time.
Much of what you see written about open education resource is is is kind of slightly rhetorical.
Sometimes you know it's a lot about the potential things that could be done, and by itself that's often enough persuasion to get things done or to get things moving.
But a lot of the time, if you're approaching a policy maker, Dean, or a politician or whoever it might be, they're going to want to see the evidence.
How does this actually work, and a large part of the movements work at the moment is advocacy effectively, so part of what we're trying to do is provide that evidence base.
So the advocates can go to people who need convincing and say, well, look.

This is the evidence that this works well, this doesn't work and also learn from other people's experiences with similar things have been tried a lot of the a lot of the time people are doing we are working in isolation from each other or they just of experimenting testing something out.
I tried making my course notes available as we are and you know, I think some people read them because we got downloads, but I'm not entirely sure what we try to do is to find ways to.
Benefit from those experiences and to share them so.
Obviously it would be nice to be able to say look we are gives you a 5% increase in student performance.
Look, grades go up.

It's very difficult to actually substantiate those sorts of claims, but it depends on the claims that you're trying to make when it comes to saving money, there's plenty of evidence to say that that people are saving money.

I'll say a little bit more about the different kinds of claims that we're looking at in a second, but for now I'd just like to convey to the idea that we're doing work that's trying to pull together diverse experiences.
So not just in the USA, although a lot of our work is and is in the USA all around the world and drawing on lots of different types of methodologies as well.
As you can imagine, it gets complicated at times.
So we we primarily interested in trying to make these things a bit simpler for everyone.
I said we work in collaboration.

I won't say too much about the collaboration aspect of the project because of time, but a lot of the the main ovr players there.
We have a really good network of people and a lot of expertise that we're able to draw on.
Around so you know the idea is always the whatever.
Whenever anyone shares data with us, we can share it back to the community.

So we try to be consistent across the collaboration across sector in terms of how we apply our research questions, the kind of methodology that we use, But in practice, you can't necessarily dictate how these things are happening.
We have a methodology we call agile research which is inspired by Agile programming an this kind of involves a lot of rethinking on the on the on the on the job.
Sometimes making the best of a situation where there's limited data available trying to make sense of it.

If you go into trying to do away or impact research with your shopping list of criteria we want to see these things, you may well be disappointed in practice is more question of working with what you can get hold of, but.
A set of hypothesis that we used to try and tie it all together.
So just briefly, these some might say that the sort of practical advantages of working in this way we're able to include everyone.
We can be quite flexible in terms of what we include in tempted the research data.
So pre judging the kinds of data that we should get in which sort of just trying to listen shape what we get in and make sense of it.
So we're very inclusive in that sense.
But from a research point of view, the price that you pay is that there is no kind of double blind controlled experiment to test what we are is doing is very very hard to isolate.
Oh we are as the thing that makes the difference.
There's also this sort of problem that we just kind of have to live with.
I think in our project about comparing these different things and trying to derive some general judgment about them.
So we say OK in the college sector in this country, we found this in the college sector in this country, but they found this.
We want to infer something about them together to say something about the influence of VR as a whole.
In practice, you can't always do that, but that problem of you might call in Commensurability is just a kind of tradeoff, really.

I'd also argue that evidence is only evidence when it's in considered in conjunction with the claim.

So audit the evidence for themselves so it's not just our judgments and our opinions about it.
So the task we set ourselves is to try and find a way of doing that.

It's fairly simple, actually, really it's just a blog entry with some metadata around which hypothesis it relates to where in the world it is, which sector it relates to, and whether in relation to a hypothesis is positive or negative.
I wouldn't worry too much about that unless you're interested.

And obviously, depending on what you write in, there is still quite open.

We're using a custom build of WordPress to do this, so.
The the word press can handle lots of different types of content, which makes it quite flexible.
We also share the.
Code openly on GitHub.
It's all CC by, so if anyone else wants to use what we've done, they can.
Martin Hawksey is our lead developer on that project.

I'm thinking about synthesis and how we kind of try and pull everything together.
We have these different pieces of metadata that help us too.
Collect things that are the same.
Collect similar kinds of data together.
We exercise as sort of a curation role ourselves in the project team in terms of what goes on.
The trick is really in sort of visualizing this stuff and pulling it all together into a place where you can make sense of it.
And in terms of the validation of that synthesis, large part of that is the patterns of evidence and whether we see the same patterns repeated in the future.
Whether we see new patterns and opening up to the community to tell us we don't agree with that, or we've got a piece of evidence you haven't seen yet, have a look at this.
